comments.commentBody:
Mark Thomasen, I have seen a few gleams of light from you lately, and want to acknowledge them. I will continue to push against simplistic characterizations and the monolithic social media distortions coming not only from the right but from the left, but I do acknowledge that you are a thoughtful person. It's tempting, and I do fall, to oversimplify. I am desperately afraid of what all the buyers-in to the purity monster have condemned us to. I know more about climate than most, and these guys are monstrous. Sessions, who is "offended" by climate science.

Have a look at the program our colleague Russell Seitz exposed in his usual humorous way. If that list doesn't give you a cauld grue, it's because you haven't become acquainted with the black is white crowd of tobacco-trained Koch-infested climate science denial.
https://vvattsupwiththat.blogspot.com/2016/12/weve-got-to-back-up-our-sc...

(Russell is a smart Republican who doesn't like nonsense.)

Your condemnation of Bolton is one such.
Two losers from New York ran for President

Here's John Oliver on "multilevel marketing". It's a shocker:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s6MwGeOm8iI

Your statement that Rex Tillerson would somehow be a voice of moderation on global warming is not correct. Exxon still supports Republican climate change deniers with hard cash. Rex is only admitting that climate change is real because his own company made that determination twenty years ago and, unlike President Trump and his other appointees, Rex was unwilling to sound like a complete idiot.

Unfortunately, Tillerson's solution is to call global warming an "engineering problem", leading to speculative solutions like carbon capture and storage. He wants the CCS contracts. This is exactly like hiring the guy who burned your house down to help you figure out how to rebuild it.

Tillerson is what he is. The Times Editorial Board is negligent in not doing its homework here. I am currently attending meetings in San Francisco during AGU about the climate emergency we are facing, and how to address it. We need one of the few remaining credible news organizations- this means you, Times- to do a little homework here. Do not be so needy and damaged from the horror of the Trump presidency to see a little sunlight in this appointment.
Rex is yet another character in the ongoing Trump horror show, brought to us by our new masters: Koch, Exxon, Chevron, and Peabody.

Mike,

You are absolutely right. Trump is an oligarch who appointed other oligarchs, generals, and some who served the oligarchy well. Tillerson falls in the latter category. Oligarchs look after the interests of their own kind. It's time the New York Times and other newspapers used the right terminology in describing the kind of nation we have became some years ago. What we now see is the in-your-face version of the corporatism we have given into.

Linda, You judge Tilllerson based on all of those meetings that you and he discussed oil exploration and global warming - right? And carbon capture and storage aren't worth exploring? Why? Doesn't fit your prescription?
You make analogies, nothing to see here.
Why oh why does a reader have to point this out? NYT's, I love you, but you are letting us down!

For heaven's sake. these are not Christians!

Jesus was not for exclusion, wealth acquisition, taking from the poor to give to the rich, or any other form of reverse Robin Hood.

Try the Gospels: they're short and repetitive.

Anyone who tells you "success" is a sign of god's favor is lying.

I have taught at public high schools for over ten years. One in the suburbs, one in the city. Both "good" schools by any measure. DeVos' schemes to privatize schools for some company's profit make me sick to my stomach. Has her shadow ever darkened the door of a public school?

Schools can be and do many amazing things for the young people they serve. Schools are necessary parts of a healthy society. For sure, Detroit has many systemic problems, and schools cannot be tasked with solving all of them. But the evidence so far shows that charters do not seem to have improved education, especially for kids in the poorest neighborhoods.

We should resist the spread of this bad scheme. It doesn't matter how many million$ a spoiled heiress throws at a bad idea. It's still a bad idea.

Failing schools are a symptom of larger social problems of course. When I went to public school in Queens decades ago most kids came from intact homes, attended school and cooperated w teachers. The teachers were good. I suspect the quality of teachers is still OK but the students are simply harder to deal w and educate. Throwing out the model for private schools sounds like a bad idea: public education is not and should not be a business. The output is an educated workforce, not widgets.

Peter:  I tutored poor kids in West Berkeley decades ago; their parents cared desperately about their children.  They did not have the resources or the money to prepare their children for the UC system.  Public schools in the Berkeley Hills had all the money they needed.  I lived in a neighborhood within walking distance from the Berkeley campus; I graduated from there.  The school system in this university town was not good; I ended up sending my daughter to a private school.  If you wanted your child to go on to university, you opted for private schools if you could afford it.  When we moved to SF, the schools were worse, and more dangerous, than Berkeley's, so more private schools.  Education majors dominated the public school system, and they were the worst educated on any campus.  You could graduate with a degree in Education without ever cracking a book.

Mike,

You are absolutely right. Trump is an oligarch who appointed other oligarchs, generals, and some who served the oligarchy well. Tillerson falls in the latter category. Oligarchs look after the interests of their own kind. It's time the New York Times and other newspapers used the right terminology in describing the kind of nation we have became some years ago. What we now see is the in-your-face version of the corporatism we have given into.
Flour+water is matzoh IF it's baked within 18 minutes of the flour getting wet.  Otherwise it's bread.
BA—I automatically assumed that the one yelling "Raid" was the person who answered the door. It would certainly be no less unwelcome if shouted by a resident.
Excellent. You're so right. Her intentions are likely good, but sounds like a dope to me...

No, madam.  What is at stake is the future of the nation and the planet.  Trump's choices are outstanding for their real life political inexperience and their opposition to the agencies they are to head.  Nothing good will come from any of them, including Trump.
My only issue with this comment is that I can only recommend it once.
It's rather disgusting when someone like De Vos has so much say in the running of a school system in which she has no stake at all.

For all of the billions we have spent since the Department of Education was created under Carter, we are little if any better of than we were in the 70's, with poor standards , teaching to tests, students who know litttle to nothing about civics or their country, etc.  The federal government has a coordinating role in education, but as it's not an enumerated power of the national government it is an area best left to the states. Somehow we managed to educate generations before D.C. started to tell us how and gave us such improvements as NCB.

"There's something sick in the head about someone who is so fixated on inserting themselves where they know nothing and are completely unwelcome."

Are we talking about DeVoss or Trump? Both are fixated on inserting themselves where they know nothing and are completely unwelcome.

This is all part of the gop plan to destroy anything that helps American's get ahead. Anything that helps the American dream for all. And to bring religion into the schools is against the law of the land. My only hope for the US is electoral college or quick impeachment and that's still not gonna help.

This administration has a Hoover feel to it. Roosevelt saved capitalism and was able to turn people away from fascism and communism through the changes he made to how the country was governed and through constraints placed on business.

It feels like we are entering the second Hoover administration, which will fail so catastrophically that it will usher in another era of - what, this time? What if we don't luck into a Rooseveltian figure after Trump?

Why is public education always at the mercy of people like this? As someone who attended public school throughout the lean Reagan years, education has been under fire my entire life. There is always some sort of ideological battle taking place between the powers that be, who have no vested interest in helping public schools succeed and absolutely no clue what it takes to foster the kind of learning that develops critical thinkers (ie: good citizens). This neo-con vision that the free-markets will solve any problem presented to us has been disproved time and again, but somehow we can't get away from it.

And hmm, I feel like I've heard something about campaign contributions and democracy... Of course, it's only natural that DeVos threatened to withhold her millions if the Republican legislators didn't acquiesce to her demand. Certainly, they did what any self-respecting politician with their career at stake would do; they took the money and shut up. And allow the poor to suffer the consequences. I don't think the majority of Americans understand that this is not how education or politics works in other democracies.

I ended up taking my daughter out of Berkeley's public school system, and later out of SF's public school system.  She went to a private French school, funded by the French government.  When she graduated, she coasted through high school.  Later she had an easy time at UC Berkeley due to that French school discipline.  Europeans educate their young before university, an excellent basic education.  They do not expect all to go on to university.  They fund good trade schools for those who don't.  We depend on property taxes to provide most funding for public schools.  The poor neighborhoods do not have high property taxes.  Berkeley resorted to busing kids all over town.  Private school became the only option.  Our public school system has been totally corrupted and dominated by poorly educated "Education" majors from State colleges.  If you are lucky to live in a well funded district, you get a good public school.  If not, you don't.

You clowns who decry choice are the classic rich liberals who read this paper.  You're all socialists until you have to get a job; you're all for social programs until they come too close to your money.  On education, you praise countries whose populations are largely homogeneous; or you claim you're a product of public ed systems far removed from the urban horror shows in places like Detroit.  All of you are so ready to "give," but not one of you will sacrifice your lifestyle to affect real change.   I'm no defender of DeVoss money or methods, but you rich liberal pukes make them tolerable.

Chris, interesting you mention Berkeley schools. I graduated from Berkeley High School. I understand from a parental point of view the inconvenience of Berkeley's busing system and lack of true neighborhood schools, and absolutely agree that relying on property taxes severely limits schools. However, BUSD created their busing system during segregation to even the playing field for African Americans and the poor. You probably know this, but they were the first school district in the country to voluntarily integrate schools. During my time at BHS there was a Frontline PBS documentary filmed on campus about this called "BHS School Colors".

Here in Eugene, our best neighborhood schools are in the most affluent neighborhoods, and while we do have school choice / lottery, there is no busing offered if you don't go to your neighborhood school. So as a result, poor people don't end up using the school choice system.

BHS during the 1990s was pretty rough, no doubt. There was graffiti everywhere - I was randomly beat up once. You had to watch your back. But I also was challenged with some really great teachers and learned how to write and think critically. I don't think private school is the answer to failing public schools. It takes investment from everyone, and not only our government.

"purposely excluded black people from the post-War boom years."
Blacks were included in the boom years in my neighborhood in Detroit and in the public schools.
Instead of draining the swamp, he's introducing invasive plants.
The minor offenses in this article and that the program has become a cash cow for local government reminded me of the underlying causes of the civil disobedience in Ferguson MO.

Mike, I think crime is something we stuck with.  The people I want to see in jail (with my tax money) are those who are a threat to society (murders, rapists, peds, those who have ripped-off thousands of people, etc), not people whose main crime is being poor, poorly educated, etc.  A program that allows people who are not a threat to stay out jail is a gift to them and us.  Saying $100k a year per inmate, having those people in jobs and paying taxes is a gift to everyone.

I was offered "diversion" which means implication of guilt as an alternative of going to court or plea bargaining. The idea of trial is an anathema to the court, they do not want it and will go out of their way to ensure that your right to trial is blocked however they can and your Attorney desperately too wants that as they have no interest in any long term commitment. Diversion programs are costly and often absurd and are just plea bargains with mo money and the same time as probation. You are not thought of as innocent nor can you expunge or seal the records which are of course limited to no facts, no testimony, no witnesses, no nothing that can at least try to prove innocence.   All facts as we have come to know are just facts and we cannot have that in America, they are just too hard to deal with.

I'm a 64-year-old woman who has lost 16 pounds this year since Jan. 1, 2016.  I had and still have a BMI in the normal category.  I lost 8 of those pounds in the last three months when I finally found what works for me: calorie restriction (paying no attention whatsoever to macronutrient percentages), regular moderate exercise, and most importantly, daily intermittent fasting (I observe a daily fasting period of at least 16 hours).  Even taking all these measures, I can only lose at the rate of half a pound a week!  It took me a long time to accept this fact and now I've slowly lost the weight figuring hey, half a pound a week is still weight loss and will eventually add up to my goal if I just accept this fact and live with it. I'm now thrilled each week to see the scale needle move down by half a pound. I could not have succeeded without the intermittent fasting.  I feel lucky and relieved to have found what works for me, even if the rate of fat loss is glacial.  I'm so clear on what works for me that I no longer ever read up on magazine articles that purport to have the latest weight loss answer.  I used to constantly read such articles looking for a solution. Now I've found my personal secret!  I intend to lose one more pound in these last two weeks leading up to Christmas and it will take discipline and focus, but at least now I'm sure I will succeed! You must find the truth of what works for you and work within those parameters - "slow and steady wins the race."

Good for you,  It appears that rapid weight loss is never sustainable.  It took me more than a decade to drop my weight from 203 pounds to the low 170's, where I have remained for more than a decade.  I had to do the weight loss in three stages.    I now have a regular exercise regimen that I believe is what helps me maintain my weight and muscle mass, delays the need for joint replacements (I am 74 years old) and generally stay fit both mentally and physically.

Yes. Let's say you eat dinner at around 5 p.m. and then nothing more other than water 12, 13 or 14 hours later which means breakfast next day at 5, 6 or 7. Other people do 8 hour windows of eating, let's say breakfast at 6 with last meal at 2. I do the first one. Second one made me starving by 4..

Google "intermittent fasting" - there are many different approaches - personally, I fast from 5:00 PM until 9:00 AM the next day, for 16 hours of fasting - I then eat my 1100 calorie allotment during the remaining 8 hours of the day - but there are *many* other ways to do it - find what works for you!
